awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Strong-Story Narrative Planning for Authoring Proactive Intelligent Virtual Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Interactive virtual worlds have a wide variety of applications, including military training simulations, classroom tutoring systems, therapeutic recreation of events, and entertainment. These worlds invite the user to take on the role of one character while the world and its cast of virtual characters are controlled by the system. Together, the user and the system create an interactive story narrative. To be meaningful and keep the user engaged, the user must be free to act and see the results of their choices, but designing all the branches of an interactive narrative by hand quickly becomes too much work for a human designer. Artificial intelligence can mitigate this problem by creating the narrative automatically as the user makes choices. This project will address several of the technical limitations that are currently preventing scientists from creating realistic, adaptive virtual environments. One key limitation is that algorithms for exploring the space of possible narratives and choosing the best one are currently too slow to be practical, especially in the face of the unpredictable choices that human beings make. Another is that it's hard for the people who design virtual environments to make sure the narratives have the right structure and teach the right information. This project will develop and test technologies that address these limitations in the context of a virtual reality training simulation that helps police officers learn how and when to use force when dealing with the communities they serve. Virtual reality training provides a safe, affordable, repeatable way to provide realistic and memorable training for dangerous situations. The artificial intelligence techniques developed for this project will make sure the training simulation is realistic and provides effective teaching no matter what choices the user makes.

Most previous approaches for using AI to control virtual environments have focused on creating realistic individual virtual humans. A world full of realistic characters can be realistic, but there is no way for the designer to impose pedagogic or aesthetic structure on the narrative, limiting their usefulness for training. This project will extend previous research on narrative planning algorithms to produce a centralized narrative planner that reasons far into the future about the user, the world, and all of its virtual characters to achieve the same level of narrative structure and quality created by hand-authored experiences, the realistic character behavior of the previously mentioned unstructured environments, and the user agency of open world environments where the player can take any action at any time. Narrative planners anticipate millions of possible futures and are constrained by models of how humans behave according to their beliefs and intentions. Planning a narrative far in advance is computationally expensive, but it can be done at a human level or better by employing non-Markovian heuristic search that accounts for narrative structure to explore only promising partial stories. These same algorithms and models can then be used to help the designers of virtual environments understand what is possible, impossible, likely, and unlikely in the virtual worlds they create. The same models of belief and intention used to model realistic virtual humans can be used to anticipate and understand the human user, and when the user acts unexpectedly, the planner's ability to anticipate millions of possibilities can adapt the narrative automatically to compensate. These algorithms will be validated through a number of computational experiments and finally by measuring their effectiveness in an adaptive virtual reality police training simulation used by real police officers.

por.por_cntn:
Virtual reality provides a safe and realistic environment where people can rehearse dangerous situations. It is used to train firefighters, police, surgeons, soldiers, and many others. VR simulations have excellent graphics, animations, and sound, but they lack the ability to create interactive stories with virtual characters that adapt automatically to the choices players make.

Most interactive stories are created in two ways. Before the simulation, writers can try to imagine everything that might happen and write a script for that outcome. Many story-based games, like Skyrim and Balder’s Gate, use this approach. This method limits the player to the choices the writers came up with in advance, and it does not scale. The second method is to fill the virtual world with individual intelligent characters. Simulation games like The Sims and Dwarf Fortress use this approach. The stories they create a randomized and highly variable. This is fine if entertainment is the only goal, but in a training simulation we need the story to have a certain structure.

This project is investigating a third approach to creating adaptive interactive stories: narrative planning algorithms. Planning is a branch of artificial intelligence research that deals with generating a sequence of actions that is guaranteed to contain certain milestones or achieve a certain goal. Narrative planning means generating a story that seems realistic but is also guaranteed to have the right structure. Training simulations that use it can rewrite their stories each time the player does something unexpected to adapt to the player’s action while preserving that structure. They offer players the same freedom they would have in an open-world simulation while also providing the structure of a hand-written story.

Over the course of five years and in partnership with the University of Kentucky Police Department, we built an interactive virtual reality training simulation for police officers to teach de-escalation tactics and best practices. Our system is perhaps the most advanced narrative planning simulation ever built, and it serves as a proof-of-concept that this approach can work in other domains.

This project accomplished three main objectives. First, we discovered several ways to speed up narrative planning. Looking far ahead to ensure a valid story exists is useful, but it’s also very expensive, because we might need to generate billions of stories before finding the right one. We developed two novel techniques to accomplish this. The first is based on a psychological phenomenon called salience. When we’re choosing a next action to add to a story, we have a better chance of finding a solution if we choose an action that reuses the characters, locations, objects, and goals that the previous actions focused on. The second is a similar technique based on causal necessity. When choosing a next action, pick one that builds on things that were accomplished by previous actions. Both methods speed up how quickly we can find stories that meet our structural and educational needs.

Being able to tell more stories than we can imagine in advance is powerful, but we have to be careful that we don’t accidentally generate a story which teaches the wrong things. For our second objective, we developed and studied two ways of summarizing all the stories that are possible in a simulation. This helps the designers ensure that only the right stories are possible.

Our third and most important objective was to improve the quality of the stories generated by our planning algorithms. Building on previous research, we developed a new method based on game theory. By reasoning about the beliefs, goals, and emotions of virtual characters, our algorithm explores billions of stories to find ones where characters take the actions that are most likely to achieve good outcomes and avoid bad ones.

For example, suppose a police officer playing our simulation pulls over a driver for speeding and finds a passenger in the car (both virtual characters). The passenger is secretly holding the driver hostage, but they know the police officer doesn’t know this, so they won’t do anything violent at first. Only after the officer learns the driver has a restraining order against the passenger will they react. This kind of complex storytelling requires reasoning about what the passenger wants, what they believe and what they believe others believe, what they expect other to do, and their emotions of fear and hope. It lets us tell more realistic stories that train officers to collect as much information as they can and to think about the goals and beliefs of the people they are interacting with.

This project supported two graduate students working towards their PhDs in Computer Science, helping to train the next generation of scientists who study artificial intelligence and virtual reality. It also led to 12 scientific publications. A ten minute video about the simulation can be seen here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NroU7cKIUR8
